results.notes: These tiny hairlike fungi, about 5 to 8mm long, were growing profusely on hardwood twigs. The stipe is capped by hairlike tufts. Under the microscope I could see hyphae and what looked like setae, but no spores, asci or conidia. The two photomicrographs show the gross morphology as seen through a 20x dissecting microscope. I have seen nothing like it before and would welcome suggestions as to its identity.

results.notes:
This seemed much too small and fragile to be a Calocera, so myself and Marcus Lopez scoped it. We found zero hymenial elements or hyphae, only oil droplets and some cuboid crystals, like these, which are byproducts of certain myxogastrids. See the “Myxomycetes Calcification” chapter of “Origin, Evolution, and Modern Aspects of Biomineralization in Plants and Animals.”

EDIT: The missing hyphae, basidia and spores have magically and inexplicably decided to show themselves in a mount made from dried tissue. Mucronella looks likely after all.

results.notes:

results.notes:
> Two basidiocarps growing in deep moss in the Prince St. bog (this collection was a close neighbor of obs 247707).
> The immediate habitat is of young red maple, Atlantic white cedar and young black gum. A few mature pitch pines stood some 15 yards away, but may still be the host tree. Despite the recent rains, the bog was unusually dry.
> I don’t think we have ever collected anything of this kind in the Pine Barrens before. It seems that this species could be restricted to this kind of habitat.
> Note the purplish-red fibrillose caps and the somewhat boletinoid, radially arranged and compound pores. The latter feature is typical of species in the genus Suillus, but this entity IMO belongs in the Boletaceae.
> The specimen were retained by J. & N. Burghardt. According to Nina, KOH was the only reagent that stained the context. The reaction was red. The exposed context stained blue, albeit very slowly, at the juncture of the stipe and cap. The pore surface stained quickly blue as well, as visible in the in situ pix.
> The older/bigger specimen has been preserved.

results.notes:
Growing grass under or around Ponderosa Pine and what appeared to be Native Arizona Oak (exact specie of oak undetermined) in the Pinetop LDS church parking lot margins. Unknown Bolete that was Red capped, yellow pore, blue staining, No reticulation on stipe, fruiting singularly and in groups, stipes were yellow tinted and had redish patterning. The largest cap was barely or just under 2" in diameter, but most were around 1" around. Spore print failed to produce noticeable spore for color or sample saving on aluminum foil. Samples were dried under low temperature and submitted to the Arizona Mushroom Society for entry to the U of A Herbarium.

Originally Reported to the AMS by Rosey Brown of Pinetop, AZ.

results.notes: Unusual small bolete found growing at 9000ft near the Hannagan Meadow Lodge in mixed conifer forrest that included Spruce, Fire, and Pine was at first was thought to be a young Boletus rubriceps, however upon examination of a previously cut sample by an unknown party the discoverer noted a lack of reticulation and an abnormally small stipe. This small (less than 4") red-brown capped bolete has yellow turning to olive pores, a ivory/white stipe with no reticulation, and no staining observed, some reddish discoloration was noticed near stipe/cap junction and along cap upon cutting, but it was apparent immediately and didn’t appear to be a staining reaction. Odor was similar to B. rubriceps, however taste was not sampled due to limited sample size. No spore print was obtained as 1/4 of cap that was placed on foil deliquesced with maggots in 24hours even though no bugs were apparent before then, rest of sample was dried under low heat for entry into the U of A herbarium collection by the Arizona Mushroom Society. Reported to the AMS by Laurie Herring-Coleman, she left three other samples in location as she was scouting the location for our annual foray two days later, this specimen was only collected since it was already cut.

results.notes:
Hydnellum aurantiacum (Batsch) P. Karst., Polyporaceae, Aphyllophorales. (Гиднеллум оранжевый).
Cap: 4-10cm, almost flat or slightly convex with cavities and bumpy, sometimes with sharp radial scales, old one slightly depressed rarely up to shallow vase or wide cone-shaped, fine velvety and radial hairy, porous in the centre; often partially overlapped, clear concentric coloured, pinkish and orange-white outer rim; central part is red with thin orange rings or orange; bottom surface looks hairy cause spines; descending; colour light pinkish-brown and darker when bruising.
Stalk: completely underground, 4-7cm long, cone-shaped as a root, uneven, stiff, orange and covered tiny roots with soil, inter grow decay wood or needles. It looks as a tree root.
Habitat: rare kind, single or small group on the ground with pine needles in pine-tree forest with some birches.
Edibility: stiff as a wood.
Season: July-August.

results.notes:
The material seen here, collected by Carolina Seas and Patty Kaishian (for which I was giddily grateful), was first suspected of being a member of the genus Ustilaginoidea, a “false smut” in the Hypocreales, at the suggestion of Dr. Priscila Chaverri. The type species of that genus is U. virens, so named for its abundant green conidia, but that species occurs on rice (Ustilaginoidea oryzae is a synonym). Of the remaining species in the genus I have had sufficient journal access to look into further, all but one occur on the inflorescences/rachises/spikelets of similar, softer grasses. The exception is Ustilaginoidea strumosa, reported from Jamaica on Chusquea; the very same genus of bamboo as this collection. The conidia, as per Cooke’s 1881 description, are “olivaceous” and found just beneath the cuticle.

A hard to find Argentinian paper from 1940 apparently details the migration of that and other spp. into Munkia, presumably on the basis of this difference in host and some other significant macro- and/or micro-morphological variation. Indeed, all Munkia spp. are bamboo inhabitants, as well as the more recently erected (and monotypic) Neomunkia. Both genera are also exclusively Neotropical. N. sydowii (or something identified as such) was collected spitting distance from Cuericí in June of 2001. This low resolution photo:

http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/...

is that collection and Fig. 1E in “this paper”: http://www.jstor.org/stable/3762091. Petrak, in his original 1947 description of the Ecuadorian type collection, describes the conidia as being “honey-yellow,” “bright honey yellow,” “pale yellowish” and “light olive brownish,” but adds the caveat that while he considered his material to be “well developed,” each fruiting body on which the description is based was still “closed,” and that older material might present some divergent features. The cross section in image four suggests that, in our material, younger, less mature conidia are this egg yolk yellow, eventually becoming olive green at maturity, as seen in both the fully ruptured specimen and the area just beneath the cortex of the cross sectioned specimen.

Of the four species of Munkia and the monotypic Neomunkia, M. strumosa and N. sydowii are the closest matches I can find in both conidial color and the dehiscent quality of the cortex/peridium layer. Both are mentioned together in Bischoff’s 2004 paper for sharing these very qualities. Ultimately, microscopy and a review of the literature will be necessary to confidently put a name on this beautiful fungus.

Host: Chusquea sp.

Habitat: High-elevation oak cloud forest

Ecoregion: Talamanca Montane Forests (NA0167)

Collectors: P. Kaishian & C. Seas

results.notes:
Pholiota (Fr.) P. Kumm.
Cap: 4-8 cm wide, convex up to broadly convex, then almost flat up with a knob; irregular colored dull orange-yellow, sometimes with tiny red spots (margin is lighter), sometimes lemon-yellow; surface smooth.
Gills: attached or slightly descending stalk, close, narrow with short and very short intermediate gills, color light orange yellow or light cream up to reddish-brown or purplish-brown when old.
Stalk: 6-13cm long, 0.8-1.4cm thick, often fine hairy, fibrous when old, irregular colored dull orange-yellow, brownish dirty yellow or purple-brown when old with light yellow top.
Edibility: no data.
Habitat: rare kind, small group around or over partially rotten stumps in deciduous forest with rare pine-trees.
July – September.

results.notes:
Fongarium: cKc0546
Date: 20.VIII.2016
Biotopes: pousse au sol, forêt mixte ;
Section Compactae

Macromorphologie
Chapeau convexe puis étalé-déprimé, infundibuliforme à maturité, ferme, glabre, mat, blanchâtre au début, puis brun grisâtre ou noirâtre, finalement entièrement noir, à marge unie 22 × 42 mm Ø ;
Lames adnées à subdécurrentes, étroites, avec nombreuses lamellules, serrées, blanc crème à chamois, noircissant au froissement ;
Pied subégal, dur, glabre, blanc, devenant grisâtre ou gris brunâtre au froissement, 19-29 × 7-11 mm Ø ;
Chair épaisse, cassante, blanche, grisonnant puis noircissant à la coupe ou au grattage ;
Odeur légère, agréable ;
Saveur douce ± mentholée ;
Sporée Leucosporée Ia-Ib d’après la charte des couleurs de Sarnari/Romagnesi et A d’après la charte des couleurs de Kibby ;
Réactions chimiques:
Soluté de gaïac endéans 5" S + (3 = moyenne) ;
Soluté de gaïac après 5" L + (3 = moyenne) ;
Remarque: cette espèce ne passe pas par le rouge lorsque coupé ou au froissement ;

Déterminé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture
results.location_name: Province of Quebec, Canada

results.notes: After a rain storm which brought down a lot of small branches I was doing a bit of yard clean-up when I noticed a creamy resupinate fungus on one branch. I threw it up on the deck for later closer inspection. It rained again and on the second day I observed some interesting changes had taken place. This series of photos documents the metamorphosis of this fungus from a cream-colored toothy resupinate growth to a purple toothy fungus with distinctive fuzzy, buff-colored caps. Individual fruit bodies are 6 mm. tall; caps are 4 mm. across. So interesting, but I have no idea what it is.

couleur: blanche ;
odeur: agréable, fongique ;
saveur: fongique avec une finale légèrement amère ;

Mode de croissance

Sporée

Gaïacol: négatives sur les lames et le pied, rose lilacée sur le chapeau après > 5’ ;

results.notes:
Hydnellum peckii Banker, Polyporaceae, Aphyllophorales. (Гиднеллум Пека).
Cap: 4-10cm wide, slightly convex and bumpy, later often flat or slightly depressed, fine velvety; milky pink or light smoky up to red-brown or pinkish-brown when depressed and old; often with red drops of juice. Tubes are small, several per 1mm, bottom surface looks somewhat velvety (very short spines) or hairy; descending; colour from milky pink up to pink and red or dark brown-red when bruising.
Stalk: completely underground, 4-7cm long, cone-shaped as a root, uneven, stiff, dark reddish-brown because covered tiny roots with soil, inter grow decay wood or needles. It looks as a tree root.
Habitat: common kind, small or big groups on the ground with pine needles in pine-tree forest with some birches.
Edibility: stiff as a wood.
Season: July-August.

Réaction macrochimique sur les Russules

Réaction au soluté alcoolique officinal de résine de gaïac sur le pied d’une Russula sp.

Ce réactif révèle les Phénoloxydases (comme d’ailleurs plusieurs autres substances) qui au contact du Gaïac, donnent plus ou moins rapidement (instantané à quelques minutes) un corps coloré en bleu dit bleu de Gaïac (voir photo ci-dessus). La réaction est donnée par l’acide bêta gaïaconique selon la réaction générale.

C’est d’ailleurs cette même réaction qui fait bleuir la résine de Gaïac à l’air, mais beaucoup plus lentement, car sans intervention d’enzyme. Il y a uniquement action de 02 de l’air donc de beaucoup, plus lente).

- soit 0 = pas de coloration bleue, mais la coloration brun pâle du réactif, pas de phénoloxydases.

- soit + =
a) Réaction bleue (phénoloxydases) qui peut varier tant en intensité (bleu clair à bleu très foncé) que dans le temps (instantanée à quelques minutes), cela dépend de la quantité et de la qualité de la phénoloxydase présente.
b) Parfois, il se produit une réaction jaune à crème jaunâtre. En effet. il arrive qu’au lieu de la réaction bleu classique, on obtienne du jaune ou du crème jaunâtre, c’est-à-dire des couleurs non orthodoxes (origine inconnue). Ainsi, sur la chair de Cortinarius aureofulvus, jaune de chrome et Cortinarius fraudulosus crème jaunâtre (réactions macrochimique chez les Cortinaires de RC Azema).

Donc, phénomène intéressant à étudier.
Aussi, en cas de réponse +, noter:
a) Si jaune ou crème jaunâtre
b) Si bleu

Noter:
1) L’intensité de la teinte obtenue (0, , + ou +) ;
2) Le temps de réaction: instantanée, rapide, assez lente, lente ou très lente.

Pour cette démonstration: réaction bleu ++, rapide (endéans de 5 secondes) ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau convexe, conique-campanulé, omboné, hygrophane, fibrilleux-squamuleux, brun cannelle imbue, brun beige à orangé sec, 8-22 mm Ø ;
Lames sinuées, larges, espacées concolore au chapeau ;
Pied cylindrique avec cortine formant une zone annuliforme, creux, chiné, parfois avec bandes annulaires, fibrilleux, légèrement concolore à plus foncé, 20-35 × 5-6 mm Ø ;
Cortine blanchâtre devenant brun rouille ;
Odeur fongique à raphanoïde ;
Saveur raphanoïde ;
Sporée brun rouille ;
Réaction chimique:
TL4: chapeau 0 ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0504-0135
Collection étudiée sur matériel déshydraté ;

Micro
Basides claviformes, rarement ventrues, tétrastérigmates, bouclées à la base, hyalines, avec contenu vacuolaire, 32,5 – 40,8 × 9 – 10,2 µm en moyenne ;
Basidiospores ellipsoïdes à courtement ellipsoïdes, parfois subcitriformes vue de front, ellipsoïdes à largement ellipsoïdes, avec parfois un angle adaxial supra-hilaire « ou avec une extrémité subfusoïdes » (M. Kuo), finement à moyennement verruqueuses, à paroi mince, appendice hilaire visible, à contenu uniguttulé, brun cannelle à brun foncé dans l’eau glycérinée 20 %, dextrinoïdes, non cyanophiles
(7,4) 7,8 – 8,6 (9) × (5,3) 5,4 – 6 (6,2) µm
Q = (1,3) 1,4 – 1,5 (1,6) ; N = 30
Me = 8,3 × 5,8 µm ; Qe = 1,4
(Piximètre: formule classique, issues d’une sporée et mesures dans l’eau glycérinée 20 %) ;
Cheilocystides absentes, mais présence nombreuses de cellules marginales polymorphes, bouclées, piriformes, claviformes, cylindriques, étroitement utriformes, ± 16,5 – 34,5 × ± 4,3 – 9,8 µm en moyenne ;
Arête lamellaire recouverte de gélatine sur presque toute sa longueur ;
Pleurocystides absentes ;
Pileipellis formé de deux couches: 1) suprapellis en cutis, constitué d’hyphes cylindriques, avec hyphes terminales obtus, souvent en biseau, 24,1 – 59,7 × 4,7 – 8,4 µm en moyenne, 2) médiopellis formé de cellules plus grandes, ellipsoïdes à largement ellipsoïdes, ovoïdales, 23 – 52,9 × 10,5 – 19,7 µm en moyenne ;
Boucles observées dans le pileipellis, dans la trame lamellaire et dans le stipe ;
Remarque: La gélatine présente sur l’arête lamellaire en couvrait une bonne partie, englobant ainsi les cellules marginales ;

results.notes:
Alone, solitary, below path with large, mostly white oaks and mixed hardwoods above. Ground cover dense low-bush blueberry immediately adjacent to path. Brick-red /pink-brown cap with ragged sterile margin, pale to medium yellow pore layer damaged by insects quickly bluing dark brown/blue, stipe enlarging downward with distinct bulge in middle. Top of stipe bright yellow with delicate /diminutive brown reticulation. Middle to base of stipe blushing bright red with intermittant ‘painted’ markings and red dots. Yellow mycelium at base of stipe. Soil sandy packed clay with gravel.
Context of cap and stipe white /pale; very weakly and slowly bluing when sectioned.
Taste mild, odor mushroomy or not distinct

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 146003544 on January 6, 2023.

results.location_name: Hunlock Creek, Luzerne Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Near Oak, Maple and White Pine. Went through all of BRB and read every Chemical reaction in the book. This is the only species I could find that matched these reactions:
KOH-on cuticle : orangish. Context Light pinkish brown, pores brownish to dark pinkish brown. Stipe N/R

NH4OH produced a green flash then turned yellow orange. context, pores, stipe, N/R
FeSO4, N/R anywhere.
